title: Plate, "Design # 18", 1930s
provenance: 2012, Damon Crain gift to Cooper-Hewitt; February 2, 2005, Damon Crain purchased from Green Valley Auctions, Inc., 2259 Green Valley Lane, Mt. Crawford, Virginia (Estate of a Connecticut collector)
dimensions: H x Diam.: 3.2 x 21 cm ( 1 1/4 x 8 1/4 in.)
description: Red circular dish with flat border and rolled rim.
justification: This plate is important to the history of Blenko and American glass techniques for two reasons, as an early representative of the stable&nbsp;ruby color that Blenko discovered, and as an example of the company's original tableware design that led to its early success. Ruby, a fugitive color, was generally unstable and therefore could not be fired a second time, necessary for the red in stained glass windows that received over decoration of enamelling.&nbsp; William Blenko, the company's founder, patented the formula in 1924, ensuring its popularity with enamellers.&nbsp; The subsequent decision in 1929 to launch a tableware line meant this color entered the field of glass tableware, previously having been reserved for ceramics.

tombstone.epitaph: Plate, "Design # 18", 1930s. Glass. Gift of Damon Crain. 2012-16-2.
